document:
The English rider crashed at this year's TT and the Fireblade bike has been plagued by mechanical problems.
Martin told MCN that he was quitting road racing but he later clarifying his position on Facebook.
"I've not given up on racing or road racing but I've got no plans to do anymore road racing on the Hondas this year," he said.
Martin didn't race at the North West 200 after team-mate John McGuinness crashed in practice and he will not compete in next month's Ulster Grand Prix.
He added: "The TT was a bloody disaster, aside from walking the dog and racing the Mugen, I didn't enjoy it.
"It was clear even before that we were going to struggle and then it turned into me really being a test rider, which I did.
"But after we did more testing at Cadwell a few weeks back, I said to the team the bike won't be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix and they decided to withdraw me from the event, although they didn't tell me, which is OK as the decision was made for me.
"There's no unfinished business and I want to race classics and oddball stuff."
claim: northern ireland\'s martin mcguinness has said he will not quit racing at the 2016 isle of man tt because of a mechanical problem.
doc_sents: The English rider crashed at this year's TT and the Fireblade bike has been plagued by mechanical problems.
Martin told MCN that he was quitting road racing but he later clarifying his position on Facebook.
"I've not given up on racing or road racing but I've got no plans to do anymore road racing on the Hondas this year," he said.
Martin didn't race at the North West 200 after team-mate John McGuinness crashed in practice and he will not compete in next month's Ulster Grand Prix.
He added: "The TT was a bloody disaster, aside from walking the dog and racing the Mugen, I didn't enjoy it.
"It was clear even before that we were going to struggle and then it turned into me really being a test rider, which I did.

"But after we did more testing at Cadwell a few weeks back, I said to the team the bike won't be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix and they decided to withdraw me from the event, although they didn't tell me, which is OK as the decision was made for me.
"There's no unfinished business and I want to race classics and oddball stuff."
sum_sents: northern ireland\'s martin mcguinness has said he will not quit racing at the 2016 isle of man tt because of a mechanical problem.

cot:
1. The summary statements are all supported by the article.
Therefore, the answer is yes, the summary is consistent with the article.
human_reason:
1. The summary states that Martin McGuinness will not quit racing at the 2016 Isle of Man TT because of a mechanical problem.
2. However, the article states that Martin crashed at this year's TT and was quitting road racing.
3. The summary mentions "Northern Ireland's Martin GcGuinness". However, the article does not mention Martin's last name as GcGuinness nor he is from northern Ireland. Instead the article states John McGuinness is Martin's teammate.
4. The summary mentions "the 2016 isle of man tt". However, the article does not mention the year of the race.
Therefore, the answer is no, the summary is not consistent with the article.
gpt-3.5-turbo-0301:

2. Martin initially announced that he was quitting road racing, but later clarified on Facebook that he has not given up on racing or road racing.
3. Martin did not race at the North West 200 and will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix.
4. Martin stated that the TT was a disaster and he did not enjoy it due to mechanical issues with the bike.
5. Martin said that he will not be racing on the Hondas this year due to the bike's lack of competitiveness.
6. Martin expressed interest in racing classics and oddball stuff.

The summary states that Martin McGuinness will not quit racing at the 2016 Isle of Man TT because of a mechanical problem. This is not consistent with the article, as Martin did not mention the Isle of Man TT in his statements and has already withdrawn from the Ulster Grand Prix due to issues with his bike's competitiveness. Therefore, the answer is no.
